Title: Strategies for mitigating nitrous oxide production and decreasing the carbon footprint of a full-scale combined nitrogen and phosphorus removal activated sludge system
Authors: Ewa Zaborowska, Xi Lu, Jacek Makinia
Abstract:
Highlights:
- An ASM2d-N2O model predicts liquid and gaseous N2O in the full-scale bioreactors
- Heterotrophic denitrification as predominant N2O production pathway
- N2O production mitigation via adjusting oxygen concentration and recirculation rate
- Potential 10% reduction in the total carbon footprint after optimization
GEMINI_What_problem_does_this_paper_atte: - The paper attempts to model and mitigate nitrous oxide ($N_2O$) production in a full-scale combined nitrogen and phosphorus removal activated sludge system.\n- It aims to decrease the overall carbon footprint of the wastewater treatment plant (WWTP).\n- It addresses the need for a simplified, yet accurate, biokinetic model (ASM2d-$N_2O$) to predict $N_2O$ emissions without overparameterization.
GEMINI_How_the_paper_solves_this_problem:
- Developed a biokinetic model (ASM2d-$N_2O$) describing $N_2O$ production and liquid-gas transfer.
- Incorporated reactions mediated by ammonia-oxidizing bacteria (AOB) and denitrifying ordinary heterotrophic organisms (OHOs), while neglecting DPAO contribution to simplify the model.
- Conducted a two-step parameter estimation and sensitivity analysis using laboratory and full-scale data.
- Simulated mitigation strategies by manipulating dissolved oxygen (DO) concentration and mixed liquor recirculation (MLR) ratio.
- Calculated the operational energy demand and carbon footprint to find an optimal balance.
GEMINI_What_experiments_were_done_for_th: - Full-scale measurement campaigns at the Slupsk WWTP (summer 2012 and 2016) to collect routine operational data.\n- Laboratory-scale batch experiments (one-phase anoxic, two-phase anaerobic-anoxic, two-phase anaerobic-aerobic) for model calibration.\n- Microsensor measurements for liquid $N_2O$ concentration and gaseous $N_2O$ emissions.
GEMINI_What_are_the_points_that_can_be_e: - The contribution of denitrifying polyphosphate accumulating organisms (DPAOs) to $N_2O$ production, which was neglected in this study.\n- Long-term dynamic validation of the model under varying seasonal conditions (e.g., winter temperatures).\n- Application and validation of the ASM2d-$N_2O$ model in other full-scale WWTP configurations.
GEMINI_Summarize_the_main_points_of_the_:
- An ASM2d-$N_2O$ model was successfully developed and validated to predict liquid and gaseous $N_2O$ in full-scale bioreactors.
- Heterotrophic denitrification was identified as the predominant $N_2O$ production pathway.
- Adjusting the DO concentration (to 1.3 mg $O_2$/L) and MLR ratio (to 730%) effectively mitigated $N_2O$ production.
- The optimized strategy led to an 11% reduction in $N_2O$ emissions and a potential 10% reduction in the total carbon footprint without compromising effluent standards.
GEMINI_What_are_the_relevant_studies:
- Lu et al. (2018) Model-Based Evaluation of N2O Production Pathways in the Anammox-Enriched Granular Sludge Cultivated in a Sequencing Batch Reactor.
- Wisniewski et al. (2018) Modeling nitrous oxide production by a denitrifying-enhanced biologically phosphorus removing (EBPR) activated sludge in the presence of different carbon sources and electron acceptors.
- Massara et al. (2018) Development of an ASM2d-N2O model to describe nitrous oxide emissions in municipal WWTPs under dynamic conditions.
- Liu et al. (2015) Mathematical Modeling of Nitrous Oxide Production during Denitrifying Phosphorus Removal Process.
- Zaborowska et al. (2017) Strategies for achieving energy neutrality in biological nutrient removal systems – a case study of the Slupsk WWTP (northern Poland).
- Foley et al. (2010) Nitrous oxide generation in full-scale biological nutrient removal wastewater treatment plants.
- Baresel et al. (2016) Comparison of nitrous oxide (N2O) emissions calculations at a Swedish wastewater treatment plant based on water concentrations versus off-gas concentrations.
- Marques et al. (2016) Assessment of online monitoring strategies for measuring N2O emissions from full-scale wastewater treatment systems.
- Kim et al. (2015) Optimization of wastewater treatment plant operation for greenhouse gas mitigation.
- Mikosz (2016) Analysis of greenhouse gas emissions and the energy balance in a model municipal wastewater treatment plant.
- Boiocchi et al. (2016) Control of wastewater N2O emissions by balancing the microbial communities using a fuzzy-logic approach.
zh_Abstract:
亮点：
- ASM2d-$N_2O$模型预测了全尺寸生物反应器中的液相和气相$N_2O$
- 异养反硝化是主要的$N_2O$产生途径
- 通过调节氧浓度和回流比来减少$N_2O$的产生
- 优化后总碳足迹有望减少10%
GEMINI_zh_What_problem_does_this_paper_a: - 本文旨在模拟和减少全尺寸脱氮除磷活性污泥系统（特别是$A^2O$或改良Bardenpho工艺）中的一氧化二氮（$N_2O$）产生。\n- 旨在降低污水处理厂（WWTP）的整体碳足迹。\n- 解决需要一个简化且准确的生物动力学模型（ASM2d-$N_2O$）来预测$N_2O$排放，同时避免参数过度参数化的问题。
GEMINI_zh_How_the_paper_solves_this_prob:
- 开发并校准了描述$N_2O$产生和液气传质的生物动力学模型（ASM2d-$N_2O$）。
- 模型结合了由氨氧化细菌（AOB）介导的反应和由反硝化普通异养生物（OHOs）介导的连续反应，同时忽略了DPAO的贡献以简化模型。
- 利用实验室规模和全尺寸测量数据进行了两步参数估计和敏感性分析。
- 使用验证后的模型，通过控制溶解氧（DO）浓度和混合液回流（MLR）比来模拟减排策略。
- 计算了运行能源需求和碳足迹，以寻找最佳平衡点。
GEMINI_zh_What_experiments_were_done_for: - 在Slupsk污水处理厂进行了全尺寸测量活动（2012年和2016年夏季），收集了常规运行数据。\n- 进行了实验室规模的批次实验（单相缺氧、两相厌氧-缺氧、两相厌氧-好氧）以校准模型。\n- 使用微传感器测量了液相$N_2O$浓度和气相$N_2O$排放量。
GEMINI_zh_What_are_the_points_that_can_b: - 反硝化聚磷菌（DPAOs）对$N_2O$产生的贡献（在此简化模型中被忽略）。\n- 在不同季节条件（如冬季温度）下对模型进行长期动态验证。\n- 将ASM2d-$N_2O$模型应用于其他全尺寸污水处理厂配置的验证。
GEMINI_zh_Summarize_the_main_points_of_t:
- 成功开发了ASM2d-$N_2O$模型，用于预测全尺寸生物反应器中的液相和气相$N_2O$。
- 确定异养反硝化是主要的$N_2O$产生途径。
- 将DO浓度调节至1.3 mg $O_2$/L，MLR比调节至730%，可有效减少$N_2O$的产生。
- 优化策略在不影响出水水质标准的前提下，使$N_2O$排放量减少了11%，总碳足迹潜在减少了10%。
GEMINI_zh_What_are_the_relevant_studies:
- Lu et al. (2018) Model-Based Evaluation of N2O Production Pathways in the Anammox-Enriched Granular Sludge Cultivated in a Sequencing Batch Reactor.
- Wisniewski et al. (2018) Modeling nitrous oxide production by a denitrifying-enhanced biologically phosphorus removing (EBPR) activated sludge in the presence of different carbon sources and electron acceptors.
- Massara et al. (2018) Development of an ASM2d-N2O model to describe nitrous oxide emissions in municipal WWTPs under dynamic conditions.
- Liu et al. (2015) Mathematical Modeling of Nitrous Oxide Production during Denitrifying Phosphorus Removal Process.
- Zaborowska et al. (2017) Strategies for achieving energy neutrality in biological nutrient removal systems – a case study of the Slupsk WWTP (northern Poland).
- Foley et al. (2010) Nitrous oxide generation in full-scale biological nutrient removal wastewater treatment plants.
- Baresel et al. (2016) Comparison of nitrous oxide (N2O) emissions calculations at a Swedish wastewater treatment plant based on water concentrations versus off-gas concentrations.
- Marques et al. (2016) Assessment of online monitoring strategies for measuring N2O emissions from full-scale wastewater treatment systems.
- Kim et al. (2015) Optimization of wastewater treatment plant operation for greenhouse gas mitigation.
- Mikosz (2016) Analysis of greenhouse gas emissions and the energy balance in a model municipal wastewater treatment plant.
- Boiocchi et al. (2016) Control of wastewater N2O emissions by balancing the microbial communities using a fuzzy-logic approach.
CLAUDE_What_problem_does_this_paper_atte:
This paper attempts to solve the following key problems:

- **$N_2O$ emissions quantification and mitigation in full-scale BNR systems**: Nitrous oxide ($N_2O$) is a potent greenhouse gas (GHG) with a global warming potential ~300 times that of $CO_2$. Wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) are significant sources of $N_2O$, yet reliable prediction and mitigation strategies for full-scale combined biological nitrogen and phosphorus removal (BNR) systems remain limited.

- **Lack of validated $N_2O$ models for full-scale $A^2O$-type systems**: Existing $N_2O$ models (e.g., Liu et al. (2015), Massara et al. (2018)) were either calibrated only on lab-scale enriched cultures or not validated against real full-scale data, making them inadequate for practical application in combined N and P removal systems.

- **Carbon footprint reduction**: The paper seeks to identify operational strategies (manipulating dissolved oxygen (DO) concentration and mixed liquor recirculation (MLR) ratio) that can simultaneously reduce $N_2O$ emissions, energy consumption, and the overall carbon footprint of a full-scale WWTP without compromising effluent quality standards.

- **Complexity of $N_2O$ production pathways in systems with DPAOs**: In systems with denitrifying polyphosphate accumulating organisms (DPAOs), the relative contributions of different microbial groups (AOB, OHOs, DPAOs) to $N_2O$ production are unclear, complicating model development and process optimization.
CLAUDE_How_the_paper_solves_this_problem:
The paper addresses these problems through a structured measurement–modeling–analysis framework:

### 1. Development of a Novel Biokinetic Model (ASM2d-$N_2O$)
- An extended ASM2d model incorporating $N_2O$ production and liquid-gas transfer was developed, implemented in GPS-X v7.0 using the Petersen-Gujer matrix notation.
- The model includes:
  - **Three AOB-mediated reactions**: (i) $NH_4^+$ oxidation to $N_2O$ (hydroxylamine pathway), (ii) $NH_4^+$ oxidation to $NO_2^-$ (nitritation), (iii) $NO_2^-$ reduction to $N_2O$ (AOB denitrification).
  - **Three OHO (heterotrophic) denitrification reactions**: (i) $NO_3^-$ → $NO_2^-$, (ii) $NO_2^-$ → $N_2O$, (iii) $N_2O$ → $N_2$.
  - **DPAOs** were assumed to reduce $NO_3^-$ only to $NO_2^-$ (following Wisniewski et al. (2018)), with negligible $N_2O$ production contribution.
  - A new state variable "$N_2O$ gas" ($C_{N_2O}$) was added to describe liquid-gas transfer.
  - $N_2O$ emission rates in aerobic zones were calculated using an empirical $kLa$ model (Foley et al., 2010); anoxic zones used a fixed $kLa_{N_2O,process}^{anoxic} = 2\ d^{-1}$.

### 2. Two-Step Calibration and Validation Procedure
- **Trial no. 1**: Laboratory-scale batch experiments (anaerobic-anoxic, anaerobic-aerobic, one-phase anoxic) and first full-scale measurement campaign were used to calibrate the base ASM2d parameters (without $N_2O$ data).
- **Trial no. 2**: Laboratory-scale experiments with low DO (0.5 mg $O_2$/L) and second full-scale measurement campaign (including liquid and gaseous $N_2O$ measurements) were used for model recalibration and validation with $N_2O$ data.
- Sensitivity analysis (one-variable-at-a-time, normalized sensitivity coefficient $S_{i,j}$) and parameter estimation (Nelder-Mead simplex method, maximum likelihood objective function) were performed in GPS-X.
- 15 parameters were adjusted, including $\eta_{NO3,H}$, $\eta_{NO2,H}$, $\eta_{N2O,H}$, $K_{O,H}$, $q_{PHA}$, $q_{PP}$, $\mu_{AOB}$, $\eta_{1,AOB}$, $\eta_{2,AOB}$, etc.

### 3. Steady-State Simulations for Mitigation Strategy Analysis
- Using routine summer 2016 operational data from the Slupsk WWTP ($A^2O$ configuration, Poland) as reference, steady-state simulations were performed by varying:
  - **DO setpoint** in the aerobic zone
  - **MLR (mixed liquor recirculation) ratio**
- The combined effect on $N_2O$ emission, energy consumption (aeration + pumping), and total carbon footprint ($CO_2$ equivalent) was evaluated.
- The optimal operating point was identified as **DO = 1.3 mg $O_2$/L** and **MLR = 730%**, achieving ~11% reduction in $N_2O$ emission and ~10% reduction in total carbon footprint without violating effluent standards (TN ≤ 10 mg N/L, TP ≤ 1 mg P/L).
CLAUDE_What_experiments_were_done_for_th:
The paper conducted both laboratory-scale and full-scale experiments in two measurement trials:

### Trial No. 1 – Laboratory-Scale Batch Experiments + First Full-Scale Campaign
**Laboratory-scale batch experiments** (at the Slupsk WWTP, Poland):
- **One-phase anoxic experiment**: Measuring $NO_3^-$-N, $PO_4^{3-}$-P, and sCOD dynamics under anoxic conditions.
- **Two-phase anaerobic-anoxic experiment**: Measuring $NO_3^-$-N, $PO_4^{3-}$-P, and sCOD in sequential anaerobic and anoxic phases.
- **Two-phase anaerobic-aerobic experiment**: Measuring $NH_4^+$-N, $PO_4^{3-}$-P, and sCOD in sequential anaerobic and aerobic phases (DO = 6.0 mg $O_2$/L).
- Purpose: Calibration of the base ASM2d parameters (without $N_2O$ data).

**First full-scale measurement campaign** (Slupsk WWTP, ~4 days):
- Continuous monitoring of $NH_4^+$-N, $NO_3^-$-N, and $PO_4^{3-}$-P in the anoxic zone (AO2) and aerobic zone (AE2).
- Purpose: Full-scale calibration/validation of the base model.

### Trial No. 2 – Laboratory-Scale Experiments with $N_2O$ + Second Full-Scale Campaign
**Laboratory-scale batch experiments with low DO** (DO = 0.5 mg $O_2$/L):
- Measuring $NH_4^+$-N, $NO_3^-$-N, $NO_2^-$-N, and liquid $N_2O$ concentrations under low-DO anoxic conditions.
- Liquid $N_2O$ was measured using a **Unisense $N_2O$ microsensor** (measurement range 0–500 µM, detection limit 0.1 µM).
- Purpose: Recalibration of the model with $N_2O$-related parameters.

**Second full-scale measurement campaign** (Slupsk WWTP, ~4 days):
- Continuous monitoring of:
  - $NH_4^+$-N, $NO_3^-$-N, $NO_2^-$-N, $PO_4^{3-}$-P in anaerobic effluent, 1st aerobic zone (AE1), and 2nd aerobic zone (AE2).
  - Liquid $N_2O$ concentration (using Unisense microsensor, temperature-compensated).
  - Gaseous $N_2O$ emission rate (kg/d) from the aerobic zone.
  - DO concentration and MLR flow rate.
- Purpose: Model validation against both conventional water quality parameters and $N_2O$ data (liquid and gaseous phases).

### Analytical Methods
- TN: TOC analyzer (TOC-VCSH) + TN module (TNM-1), SHIMADZU.
- COD, TP: Cuvette tests (Hach Lange) in Xion 500 spectrophotometer.
- sCOD, $NH_4^+$-N, $NO_3^-$-N, $NO_2^-$-N: Cuvette tests after vacuum filtration (Whatman GF/C).
- TSS, VSS, MLSS, MLVSS, TKN: Standard methods (APHA, 2005).
- Routine operational data from summer 2016 (June–September): flow rate ~6025 m³/d per line, T = 20.4°C, MLSS = 3.9 g/L, SRT = 20 d, RAS = 100%, MLR = 500% of influent.
CLAUDE_What_are_the_points_that_can_be_e:
Based on the paper's findings and limitations, the following aspects warrant further investigation:

- **Role of DPAOs in $N_2O$ production**: The paper simplifies DPAO contribution to $N_2O$ as negligible. However, under certain conditions (e.g., different carbon sources, varying electron acceptor availability), DPAOs may contribute significantly. More detailed experimental and modeling work on DPAO-mediated $N_2O$ production (as in Liu et al. (2015) and Wisniewski et al. (2018)) is needed.

- **Winter/seasonal operational conditions**: The optimization was based on summer 2016 data (T ≈ 20°C). The effect of lower temperatures on $N_2O$ production pathways, model parameters (Arrhenius coefficients), and optimal DO/MLR settings should be investigated for year-round applicability.

- **Dynamic real-time control strategies**: The paper uses steady-state simulations for optimization. Implementing dynamic (real-time) control of DO and MLR based on online $N_2O$ sensors could further reduce emissions and improve energy efficiency.

- **$N_2O$ production under transient/dynamic loading conditions**: The full-scale WWTP experiences significant diurnal and seasonal flow/load variations. Dynamic simulation-based optimization under varying influent conditions would provide more robust mitigation strategies.

- **Integration with plant-wide GHG accounting**: The paper focuses on direct $N_2O$ emissions and aeration/pumping energy. A comprehensive plant-wide carbon footprint analysis including sludge treatment, methane ($CH_4$) emissions, and chemical usage would give a more complete picture.

- **Validation at other WWTP configurations**: The ASM2d-$N_2O$ model was developed and validated only for the modified Bardenpho ($A^2O$) configuration at Slupsk WWTP. Its applicability to other configurations (e.g., step-feed, SBR, MBR, Carrousel) needs to be tested.

- **NOB suppression strategies**: The paper mentions that enhancing NOB activity can reduce $N_2O$ but at the cost of effluent quality (Boiocchi et al., 2016). Partial nitritation/anammox or NOB suppression strategies combined with $N_2O$ mitigation deserve further exploration.

- **Uncertainty and sensitivity of $N_2O$-related parameters**: The paper identifies $\eta_{NO2,H}$, $\eta_{N2O,H}$, $K_{NO2,H}$, and $K_{N2O,H}$ as (very) influential to $N_2O$ predictions. More rigorous uncertainty analysis and identifiability studies for these parameters are needed.

- **Online $N_2O$ monitoring integration**: The use of $N_2O$ microsensors for model calibration is promising but requires further development of robust, low-maintenance online sensors suitable for long-term full-scale deployment.

- **Economic analysis of mitigation strategies**: A detailed cost-benefit analysis comparing the capital and operational costs of implementing DO/MLR optimization versus the benefits of reduced GHG emissions and energy savings would strengthen the practical case for adoption.
CLAUDE_Summarize_the_main_points_of_the_:
This paper presents a comprehensive measurement–modeling–analysis study on $N_2O$ production, emission, and mitigation strategies at a full-scale combined nitrogen and phosphorus removal activated sludge system (modified Bardenpho/$A^2O$ configuration) at the Slupsk WWTP in Poland. The main points are:

### 1. Development of ASM2d-$N_2O$ Model
- A novel biokinetic model (ASM2d-$N_2O$) was developed by extending ASM2d to include $N_2O$ production by AOB (hydroxylamine oxidation and AOB denitrification) and heterotrophic OHOs (incomplete denitrification via $NO_2^-$ and $N_2O$ as intermediates), as well as liquid-gas $N_2O$ transfer.
- DPAOs were assumed to reduce $NO_3^-$ only to $NO_2^-$ with negligible $N_2O$ production, simplifying the model structure.
- The model was implemented in GPS-X v7.0 using the Petersen-Gujer matrix notation.

### 2. Two-Step Calibration and Validation
- A rigorous two-step calibration procedure was applied: first calibrating base ASM2d parameters (without $N_2O$ data) using lab-scale batch experiments and the first full-scale campaign, then recalibrating $N_2O$-related parameters using low-DO lab experiments and validating against the second full-scale campaign (including liquid and gaseous $N_2O$ measurements).
- The model achieved good agreement with measured data: $r = 0.83–0.91$ for $NH_4^+$-N, $r = 0.64$ for $PO_4^{3-}$-P, and $r = 0.91$ for $NO_3^-$-N in the aerobic zones.
- The reference state $N_2O$ emission factor was 1.6% of TN load, consistent with literature values for similar systems.

### 3. Identification of Predominant $N_2O$ Production Pathway
- Heterotrophic denitrification (OHO-mediated incomplete denitrification, particularly $NO_2^-$ → $N_2O$) was identified as the predominant $N_2O$ production pathway in this full-scale BNR system, rather than AOB-mediated pathways.

### 4. Mitigation Strategy Analysis via Steady-State Simulations
- Steady-state simulations varying DO concentration (in aerobic zones) and MLR ratio were performed using summer 2016 routine operational data as the reference.
- The optimal operating conditions were identified as **DO = 1.3 mg $O_2$/L** and **MLR = 730%** of influent flow.
- At the optimum: $N_2O$ emission reduced by ~11%, energy demand reduced, and total carbon footprint reduced by ~10%, without violating EU effluent standards (TN ≤ 10 mg N/L, TP ≤ 1 mg P/L).

### 5. Carbon Footprint Analysis
- The total carbon footprint was calculated as $CO_2$ equivalent emissions, combining direct $N_2O$ emissions (converted using GWP factor) and indirect emissions from energy consumption (aeration blowers and pumps).
- The study demonstrated that simultaneous reduction of $N_2O$ emissions and energy consumption is achievable through operational optimization, providing a practical pathway to reduce the carbon footprint of full-scale WWTPs.

- Swinarski et al. (2012): *Modeling External Carbon Addition in Biological Nutrient Removal Processes with an Extension of the International Water Association Activated Sludge Model.* Water Environ. Res. 84, 646–655.

- Wang et al. (2016): *Nitric oxide and nitrous oxide emissions from a full-scale activated sludge anaerobic/anoxic/oxic process.* Chem. Eng. J. 289, 330–340.

- Wisniewski et al. (2018): *Modeling nitrous oxide production by a denitrifying-enhanced biologically phosphorus removing (EBPR) activated sludge in the presence of different carbon sources and electron acceptors.* Water Research, 142, 55–64.

- Zaborowska et al. (2017): *Strategies for achieving energy neutrality in biological nutrient removal systems – a case study of the Slupsk WWTP (northern Poland).* Water Sci. Technol. 75, 727–740.
CLAUDE_zh_What_problem_does_this_paper_a:
本文试图解决以下几个关键问题：

- **全规模BNR系统中$N_2O$排放的量化与减排**：氧化亚氮（$N_2O$）是一种强效温室气体，其全球增温潜势约为$CO_2$的300倍。污水处理厂（WWTPs）是$N_2O$的重要排放源，但针对全规模联合生物脱氮除磷（BNR）系统的可靠预测和减排策略仍然十分有限。

- **缺乏适用于全规模$A^2O$型系统的验证$N_2O$模型**：现有$N_2O$模型（如Liu et al. (2015)、Massara et al. (2018)）要么仅在实验室规模的富集培养物上进行了标定，要么根本未经实际数据验证，无法有效应用于联合脱氮除磷系统的实际工程。

- **降低碳足迹**：本文旨在通过调节溶解氧（DO）浓度和混合液回流（MLR）比例，识别能够同时减少$N_2O$排放、降低能耗并减小全规模污水处理厂总体碳足迹的运行策略，同时不影响出水水质达标。

- **含DPAOs系统中$N_2O$产生途径的复杂性**：在含有反硝化聚磷菌（DPAOs）的系统中，不同微生物群体（AOB、OHOs、DPAOs）对$N_2O$产生的相对贡献尚不明确，这给模型开发和工艺优化带来了困难。
CLAUDE_zh_How_the_paper_solves_this_prob:
本文通过"测量–建模–分析"的结构化框架解决上述问题：

### 1. 开发新型生物动力学模型（ASM2d-$N_2O$）
- 在ASM2d基础上扩展开发了包含$N_2O$产生和液气传质的新模型，在GPS-X v7.0平台中采用Petersen-Gujer矩阵符号实现。
- 模型包含：
  - **AOB介导的三个酶促反应**：(i) $NH_4^+$氧化为$N_2O$（羟胺氧化途径），(ii) $NH_4^+$氧化为$NO_2^-$（亚硝化），(iii) $NO_2^-$还原为$N_2O$（AOB反硝化）。
  - **OHO（异养菌）反硝化的三个顺序反应**：(i) $NO_3^-$ → $NO_2^-$，(ii) $NO_2^-$ → $N_2O$，(iii) $N_2O$ → $N_2$。
  - **DPAOs**假设仅将$NO_3^-$还原为$NO_2^-$（遵循Wisniewski et al. (2018)的概念），$N_2O$产生贡献可忽略不计，从而简化了模型结构。
  - 新增状态变量"$N_2O$气体"（$C_{N_2O}$）以描述液气传质过程。
  - 好氧区$N_2O$排放速率采用经验$kLa$模型（Foley et al., 2010）计算；缺氧区采用固定值$kLa_{N_2O,process}^{anoxic} = 2\ d^{-1}$。

### 2. 两步标定与验证程序
- **第一轮（Trial no. 1）**：利用实验室规模批次实验（缺氧、厌氧-缺氧、厌氧-好氧）和第一次全规模测量活动，标定基础ASM2d参数（不含$N_2O$数据）。
- **第二轮（Trial no. 2）**：利用低DO（0.5 mg $O_2$/L）实验室实验和第二次全规模测量活动（含液相和气相$N_2O$测量数据），对$N_2O$相关参数进行重新标定和验证。
- 在GPS-X中进行了灵敏度分析（单变量法，归一化灵敏度系数$S_{i,j}$）和参数估计（Nelder-Mead单纯形法，最大似然目标函数）。
- 共调整了15个参数，包括$\eta_{NO3,H}$、$\eta_{NO2,H}$、$\eta_{N2O,H}$、$K_{O,H}$、$q_{PHA}$、$q_{PP}$、$\mu_{AOB}$、$\eta_{1,AOB}$、$\eta_{2,AOB}$等。

### 3. 基于稳态模拟的减排策略分析
- 以2016年夏季Slupsk污水处理厂的常规运行数据为参考，通过改变好氧区DO设定值和MLR比例进行稳态模拟。
- 最优运行条件确定为**DO = 1.3 mg $O_2$/L**，**MLR = 730%**（进水流量的730%）。
- 在最优点：$N_2O$排放减少约11%，能耗降低，总碳足迹减少约10%，同时满足欧盟出水标准（TN ≤ 10 mg N/L，TP ≤ 1 mg P/L）。
CLAUDE_zh_What_experiments_were_done_for:
本文在两个测量轮次中开展了实验室规模和全规模实验：

### 第一轮（Trial No. 1）——实验室批次实验 + 第一次全规模测量活动
**实验室规模批次实验**（在Slupsk污水处理厂进行）：
- **单相缺氧实验**：测量缺氧条件下$NO_3^-$-N、$PO_4^{3-}$-P和sCOD的动态变化。
- **两相厌氧-缺氧实验**：测量厌氧和缺氧顺序阶段中$NO_3^-$-N、$PO_4^{3-}$-P和sCOD的变化。
- **两相厌氧-好氧实验**：测量厌氧和好氧顺序阶段中$NH_4^+$-N、$PO_4^{3-}$-P和sCOD的变化（DO = 6.0 mg $O_2$/L）。
- 目的：标定基础ASM2d参数（不含$N_2O$数据）。

**第一次全规模测量活动**（Slupsk污水处理厂，约4天）：
- 连续监测缺氧区（AO2）和好氧区（AE2）的$NH_4^+$-N、$NO_3^-$-N和$PO_4^{3-}$-P。
- 目的：全规模模型标定/验证。

### 第二轮（Trial No. 2）——含$N_2O$的实验室实验 + 第二次全规模测量活动
**低DO实验室批次实验**（DO = 0.5 mg $O_2$/L）：
- 测量低DO缺氧条件下$NH_4^+$-N、$NO_3^-$-N、$NO_2^-$-N和液相$N_2O$浓度。
- 液相$N_2O$采用**Unisense $N_2O$微传感器**测量（量程0–500 µM，检测限0.1 µM）。
- 目的：重新标定$N_2O$相关参数。

**第二次全规模测量活动**（Slupsk污水处理厂，约4天）：
- 连续监测：
  - 厌氧出水、第一好氧区（AE1）和第二好氧区（AE2）的$NH_4^+$-N、$NO_3^-$-N、$NO_2^-$-N、$PO_4^{3-}$-P。
  - 液相$N_2O$浓度（Unisense微传感器，经温度补偿）。
  - 好氧区气相$N_2O$排放速率（kg/d）。
  - DO浓度和MLR流量。
- 目的：对常规水质参数和$N_2O$数据（液相和气相）进行模型验证。

### 分析方法
- TN：TOC分析仪（TOC-VCSH）+ TN模块（TNM-1），岛津公司。
- COD、TP：Hach Lange比色管法，Xion 500分光光度计。
- sCOD、$NH_4^+$-N、$NO_3^-$-N、$NO_2^-$-N：真空过滤（Whatman GF/C）后比色管法测定。
- TSS、VSS、MLSS、MLVSS、TKN：标准方法（APHA, 2005）。
- 常规运行数据来自2016年夏季（6–9月）：流量约6025 m³/d（每条线），T = 20.4°C，MLSS = 3.9 g/L，SRT = 20 d，RAS = 100%，MLR = 500%进水流量。
CLAUDE_zh_What_are_the_points_that_can_b:
根据本文的研究发现和局限性，以下方面值得进一步探索：

- **DPAOs对$N_2O$产生的贡献**：本文将DPAO对$N_2O$的贡献简化为可忽略不计。然而，在某些条件下（如不同碳源、不同电子受体），DPAOs可能有显著贡献。需要更详细的实验和建模工作（如Liu et al. (2015)和Wisniewski et al. (2018)的研究方向）。

- **冬季/季节性运行条件**：本文优化基于2016年夏季数据（T ≈ 20°C）。低温对$N_2O$产生途径、模型参数（Arrhenius系数）以及最优DO/MLR设定的影响应进行研究，以实现全年适用性。

- **动态实时控制策略**：本文采用稳态模拟进行优化。基于在线$N_2O$传感器对DO和MLR实施动态（实时）控制，可进一步减少排放并提高能效。

- **动态/瞬态负荷条件下的$N_2O$产生**：全规模污水处理厂存在显著的日变化和季节性流量/负荷波动。基于动态模拟的优化将提供更稳健的减排策略。

- **全厂温室气体核算的整合**：本文聚焦于直接$N_2O$排放和曝气/泵送能耗。包含污泥处理、甲烷（$CH_4$）排放和化学品使用的全厂碳足迹综合分析将提供更完整的评估。

- **在其他污水处理厂构型中的验证**：ASM2d-$N_2O$模型仅在Slupsk污水处理厂的改良Bardenpho（$A^2O$）构型中开发和验证。其在其他构型（如分段进水、SBR、MBR、Carrousel）中的适用性需要测试。

- **NOB抑制策略**：本文提到增强NOB活性可减少$N_2O$，但会牺牲出水水质（Boiocchi et al., 2016）。部分亚硝化/厌氧氨氧化或NOB抑制策略与$N_2O$减排的结合值得进一步探索。

- **$N_2O$相关参数的不确定性和可辨识性**：本文识别出$\eta_{NO2,H}$、$\eta_{N2O,H}$、$K_{NO2,H}$和$K_{N2O,H}$对$N_2O$预测（非常）敏感。需要对这些参数进行更严格的不确定性分析和可辨识性研究。

- **在线$N_2O$监测的集成应用**：$N_2O$微传感器用于模型标定的方法很有前景，但需要进一步开发适合长期全规模部署的稳健、低维护在线传感器。

- **减排策略的经济性分析**：对实施DO/MLR优化的资本和运营成本与减少温室气体排放及节能效益进行详细的成本效益分析，将增强实际推广应用的说服力。
CLAUDE_zh_Summarize_the_main_points_of_t:
本文针对波兰Slupsk污水处理厂全规模联合脱氮除磷活性污泥系统（改良Bardenpho/$A^2O$构型），开展了系统性的"测量–建模–分析"研究，主要内容如下：

### 1. 开发ASM2d-$N_2O$模型
- 通过扩展ASM2d，开发了包含AOB介导的$N_2O$产生（羟胺氧化途径和AOB反硝化途径）、异养OHO不完全反硝化（以$NO_2^-$和$N_2O$为中间产物）以及液气$N_2O$传质的新型生物动力学模型（ASM2d-$N_2O$）。
- DPAOs假设仅将$NO_3^-$还原为$NO_2^-$，$N_2O$产生贡献可忽略，从而简化了模型结构。
- 模型在GPS-X v7.0平台中采用Petersen-Gujer矩阵符号实现。

### 2. 两步标定与验证
- 采用严格的两步标定程序：首先利用实验室批次实验和第一次全规模测量活动标定基础ASM2d参数（不含$N_2O$数据），再利用低DO实验室实验和第二次全规模测量活动（含液相和气相$N_2O$测量）重新标定$N_2O$相关参数并进行验证。
- 模型与测量数据吻合良好：好氧区$NH_4^+$-N的$r = 0.83–0.91$，$PO_4^{3-}$-P的$r = 0.64$，$NO_3^-$-N的$r = 0.91$。
- 参考状态下$N_2O$排放因子为TN负荷的1.6%，与文献中同类系统的数值一致。

### 3. 识别主导$N_2O$产生途径
- 在该全规模BNR系统中，异养反硝化（OHO介导的不完全反硝化，尤其是$NO_2^-$ → $N_2O$步骤）被识别为主导$N_2O$产生途径，而非AOB介导的途径。

### 4. 基于稳态模拟的减排策略分析
- 以2016年夏季常规运行数据为参考，通过改变好氧区DO浓度和MLR比例进行稳态模拟。
- 最优运行条件确定为**DO = 1.3 mg $O_2$/L**，**MLR = 730%**进水流量。
- 在最优点：$N_2O$排放减少约11%，能耗降低，总碳足迹减少约10%，同时满足欧盟出水标准（TN ≤ 10 mg N/L，TP ≤ 1 mg P/L）。

### 5. 碳足迹分析
- 总碳足迹以$CO_2$当量排放量计算，综合考虑直接$N_2O$排放（按GWP系数换算）和能耗间接排放（曝气风机和水泵）。
- 研究表明，通过运行优化可同时实现$N_2O$排放减少和能耗降低，为全规模污水处理厂降低碳足迹提供了切实可行的途径。
CLAUDE_zh_What_are_the_relevant_studies:
以下为本文参考文献中出现的相关研究：

- Aboobakar et al. (2013): *Nitrous oxide emissions and dissolved oxygen profiling in a full-scale nitrifying activated sludge treatment plant.* Water Res. 47, 524–534.

- Ahn et al. (2010): *N2O Emissions from Activated Sludge Processes, 2008–2009: Results of a National Monitoring Survey in the United States.* Environ. Sci. Technol. 44, 4505–4511.

- Baresel et al. (2016): *Comparison of nitrous oxide (N2O) emissions calculations at a Swedish wastewater treatment plant based on water concentrations versus off-gas concentrations.* Adv. Clim. Change Res. 7, 185–191.

- Boiocchi et al. (2016): *Control of wastewater N2O emissions by balancing the microbial communities using a fuzzy-logic approach.* IFAC-PapersOnLine, 49-7, 1157–1162.

- Daelman et al. (2015): *Seasonal and diurnal variability of N2O emissions from a full-scale municipal wastewater treatment plant.* Sci. Total Environ. 536, 1–11.

- Drewnowski et al. (2013): *Modeling hydrolysis of slowly biodegradable organic compounds in biological nutrient removal activated sludge systems.* Water Science & Technology 67(9):2067–74.

- Eldyasti et al. (2012): *Development of a calibration protocol and identification of the most sensitive parameters for the particulate biofilm models used in biological wastewater treatment.* Bioresour. Technol. 111, 111–121.

- Foley et al. (2010): *Nitrous oxide generation in full-scale biological nutrient removal wastewater treatment plants.* Water Res. 44, 831–844.

- Henze et al. (2000): *Activated Sludge Models ASM1, ASM2, ASM2d and ASM3.* IWA Publ., London.

- Hiatt et al. (2008): *An Updated Process Model for Carbon Oxidation, Nitrification, and Denitrification.* Water Environ. Res. 80, 2145–2156.

- Hulsbeek et al. (2002): *A practical protocol for dynamic modelling of activated sludge systems.* Water Sci. Technol. 45(6), 127–136.

- Kim et al. (2015): *Optimization of wastewater treatment plant operation for greenhouse gas mitigation.* Journal of Environmental Management, 163, 39–48.

- Langergraber et al. (2004): *A guideline for simulation studies of wastewater treatment plants.* Water Sci. Technol. 50(7), 131–138.

- Liu et al. (2015): *Mathematical Modeling of Nitrous Oxide Production during Denitrifying Phosphorus Removal Process.* Environ. Sci. Technol., 49, 8595–8601.

- Lu et al. (2018): *Model-Based Evaluation of N2O Production Pathways in the Anammox-Enriched Granular Sludge Cultivated in a Sequencing Batch Reactor.* Environ. Sci. Technol., 52, 2800–2809.

- Law et al. (2012): *N2O production rate of an enriched ammonia-oxidising bacteria culture exponentially correlates to its ammonia oxidation rate.* Water Res. 46, 3409–3419.

- Makinia et al. (2006): *Comparison of Two Model Concepts for Simulation of Nitrogen Removal at a Full-Scale Biological Nutrient Removal Pilot Plant.* J. Environ. Eng. 132, 476–487.

- Mannina et al. (2018): *A comprehensive integrated membrane bioreactor model for greenhouse gas emissions.* Chem. Eng. J. 334, 1563–1572.

- Mannina et al. (2012): *Uncertainty assessment of a model for biological nitrogen and phosphorus removal: Application to a large wastewater treatment plant.* Phys. Chem. Earth Parts ABC 42–44, 61–69.

- Marques et al. (2016): *Assessment of online monitoring strategies for measuring N2O emissions from full-scale wastewater treatment systems.* Water Res. 99, 171–179.

- Massara et al. (2018): *Development of an ASM2d-N2O model to describe nitrous oxide emissions in municipal WWTPs under dynamic conditions.* Chem. Eng. J., 335, 185–196.

- Meijer et al. (2001): *Metabolic modelling of full-scale biological nitrogen and phosphorus removing wwtp's.* Water Res. 35, 2711–2723.

- Mikosz (2016): *Analysis of greenhouse gas emissions and the energy balance in a model municipal wastewater treatment plant.* Desalination Water Treat., 57, 28551–28559.

- Ni et al. (2011): *Modeling Nitrous Oxide Production during Biological Nitrogen Removal via Nitrification and Denitrification: Extensions to the General ASM Models.* Environ. Sci. Technol. 45, 7768–7776.

- Ni et al. (2013a): *Mathematical Modeling of Nitrous Oxide (N2O) Emissions from Full-Scale Wastewater Treatment Plants.* Environ. Sci. Technol. 47, 7795–7803.

- Ni et al. (2013b): *Evaluating four mathematical models for nitrous oxide production by autotrophic ammonia-oxidizing bacteria.* Biotechnol. Bioeng. 110, 153–163.

- Ni et al. (2015): *Full-Scale Modeling Explaining Large Spatial Variations of Nitrous Oxide Fluxes in a Step-Feed Plug-Flow Wastewater Treatment Reactor.* Environ. Sci. Technol. 49, 9176–9184.

- Pan et al. (2013): *Modeling Electron Competition among Nitrogen Oxides Reduction and N2O Accumulation in Denitrification.* Environ. Sci. Technol. 47, 11083–11091.

- Pan et al. (2016): *Unravelling the spatial variation of nitrous oxide emissions from a step-feed plug-flow full scale wastewater treatment plant.* Sci. Rep., 6:20792, 1–10.

- Petersen et al. (2002): *Evaluation of an ASM1 model calibration procedure on a municipal-industrial wastewater treatment plant.* J. Hydroinformatics 4(1), 15–38.

- Rodriguez-Caballero et al. (2014): *Evaluation of process conditions triggering emissions of green-house gases from a biological wastewater treatment system.* Sci. Total Environ. 493, 384–391.

- Rodriguez-Caballero et al. (2015): *Minimizing N2O emissions and carbon footprint on a full-scale activated sludge sequencing batch reactor.* Water Res. 71, 1–10.

- Sarioglu et al. (2017): *Dynamic modeling of nutrient removal by a MBR operated at elevated temperatures.* Water Res. 123, 420–428.

- Schulthess et al. (1996): *Release of nitrous oxide (N2O) from denitrifying activated sludge: Verification and application of a mathematical model.* Water Res. 30, 521–530.

- Sun et al. (2015): *Study on emission characteristics and reduction strategy of nitrous oxide during wastewater treatment by different processes.* Environ Sci Pollut Res 22:4222–4229.
